qas.question: What is Avicenna's Book of Healing referred to in Arabic?
What subject is seen throughout Avicenna's Book of Healing?
In an argument by Avicenna, the soul is without what?
Whose argument is similar to Avicenna's that the soul is without quantitative extension?
What is the Latin for Avicenna's psychology parts in his Book of Healing?
What text embodies Avicenna's legacy in philosophy?
What kind of extension does Avicenna say the soul has?
Who's agrument disagrees with Avicenna's argument on the soul?
What is Avicenna's Book of Healing referred to in Muslim?
What subject is never seen throughout Avicenna's Book of Healing?
In an argument by Avicenna, the soul is with what?
Whose argument is similar to Avicenna's that the soul is with quantitative extension?
What is the Latin for Avicenna's philosophy parts in his Book of Healing?

context: Avicenna's legacy in <a1_0><b9_0>classical psychology<b9_0/><a1_0/> is primarily embodied in the <b5_0>Kitab al-nafs<b5_0/> parts of his <a0_0><b8_0>Kitab al-shifa<b8_0/><a0_0/> (The Book of Healing) and Kitab al-najat (The Book of Deliverance). These were known in Latin under the title <a4_0><b12_0>De Anima<b12_0/><a4_0/> (treatises "on the soul").[dubious – discuss] Notably, Avicenna develops what is called the "flying man" argument in the Psychology of The Cure I.1.7 as defense of the argument that the soul is without <a2_0><b6_0><b10_0>quantitative<b6_0/> extension<b10_0/><a2_0/>, which has an affinity with <a3_0><b7_0><b11_0>Descartes<b11_0/><a3_0/>'s<b7_0/> cogito argument (or what phenomenology designates as a form of an "epoche").
